[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: Dependency, Field: local] [Path Traversal] Can an attacker craft a malicious manifest with Dependency.local containing path traversal sequences like '../../../etc/passwd' to read arbitrary files on validator nodes during package compilation, potentially exposing private keys or configuration files? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: Dependency, Field: local] [Symlink Attack] Does the Dependency.local PathBuf validation prevent symlink attacks where a malicious package creates a symlink in the dependency path pointing to sensitive system directories, allowing arbitrary file access during build? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: Dependency, Field: local] [Directory Escape] Can Dependency.local contain absolute paths (e.g., '/root/.ssh/') that escape the intended package directory sandbox, potentially allowing malicious packages to write compiled artifacts to arbitrary filesystem locations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: Dependency, Field: local] [Race Condition] If multiple packages are built concurrently and share overlapping Dependency.local paths, can a TOCTOU (time-of-check-time-of-use) race condition allow one package to modify dependency files while another is reading them, leading to inconsistent compilation results? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: Dependency, Field: local] [Resource Exhaustion] Can an attacker specify a Dependency.local path pointing to an extremely deep directory structure (e.g., 10000+ nested directories) to cause stack overflow or excessive memory consumption during path canonicalization? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: GitInfo, Field: git_url] [Command Injection] Can an attacker craft a malicious GitInfo.git_url containing shell metacharacters or command substitution syntax (e.g., 'https://evil.com/$(rm -rf /)') that gets executed when the git clone command is invoked, achieving remote code execution on validator nodes? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: GitInfo, Field: git_url] [URL Validation] Does GitInfo.git_url validation prevent dangerous protocols like 'file://', 'ftp://', or 'git+ssh://' that could be exploited to access local files or bypass network restrictions during dependency fetching? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: GitInfo, Field: git_rev] [Commit Pinning] Can an attacker specify a GitInfo.git_rev pointing to a branch name (e.g., 'main') instead of a commit SHA, allowing them to update the malicious code in the git repository after package hash verification, leading to supply chain attacks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: GitInfo, Field: git_rev] [Hash Collision] If GitInfo.git_rev allows shortened commit SHAs (e.g., 7 characters), can an attacker find a collision to point to a malicious commit that matches the prefix of a legitimate commit, bypassing integrity checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: GitInfo, Field: subdir] [Path Traversal in Git Subdir] Can GitInfo.subdir contain '../' sequences to escape the git repository root, potentially accessing files outside the cloned repository during package compilation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: GitInfo, Field: download_to] [Download Path Manipulation] Can an attacker control GitInfo.download_to to download malicious git repositories to sensitive system directories (e.g., '/usr/bin/'), overwriting system executables and achieving persistent compromise? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: GitInfo] [Git Clone Exploits] Does the GitInfo struct protect against malicious git repositories containing git hooks, submodules pointing to attacker-controlled servers, or specially crafted git objects that exploit git client vulnerabilities? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: GitInfo] [SSRF via Git URL] Can GitInfo.git_url be exploited for Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) attacks by pointing to internal network addresses (e.g., 'http://169.254.169.254/metadata') to access cloud metadata services or internal APIs? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: CustomDepInfo, Field: node_url] [Node URL Injection] Can an attacker craft CustomDepInfo.node_url with malicious URLs containing authentication credentials, redirect chains, or request smuggling payloads to compromise the package resolution infrastructure? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: CustomDepInfo, Field: package_address] [Address Spoofing] Can CustomDepInfo.package_address be manipulated to point to a malicious package at an address that looks similar to a legitimate package address (e.g., using Unicode lookalike characters), causing dependency confusion attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: CustomDepInfo, Field: package_name] [Package Name Collision] If CustomDepInfo.package_name uses Symbol without namespace isolation, can an attacker register a package with the same name as a popular legitimate package, causing developers to inadvertently include malicious code? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: CustomDepInfo, Field: download_to] [Download Directory Hijacking] Can CustomDepInfo.download_to be manipulated to write downloaded packages to system directories or other packages' directories, enabling file overwrite attacks or code injection into trusted packages? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: CustomDepInfo] [Node Resolver Exploitation] Does CustomDepInfo provide sufficient validation for the 'node_url' and 'package_address' fields to prevent malicious node resolvers from returning arbitrary code that gets executed during package resolution? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Type: Version, Line: 16] [Integer Overflow] Can the Version tuple (u64, u64, u64) overflow during arithmetic operations (e.g., version comparison or increment) if an attacker specifies extremely large version numbers like (u64::MAX, u64::MAX, u64::MAX), leading to incorrect dependency resolution? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: PackageInfo, Field: version] [Version Downgrade] Can an attacker exploit missing version validation in PackageInfo.version to specify older vulnerable versions of dependencies, bypassing security patches and introducing known vulnerabilities into the build? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: Dependency, Field: version] [Version Mismatch] If Dependency.version is Optional, can a None value lead to inconsistent behavior where different build systems resolve to different dependency versions, causing non-deterministic builds and potential consensus failures? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Display: PackageInfo.fmt, Lines: 64-68] [Version Format Injection] Can malicious version numbers in PackageInfo.version.fmt() output contain format string specifiers or escape sequences that exploit downstream parsers, log injection, or terminal control sequences? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Struct: BuildInfo, Field: language_version] [Language Version Mismatch] Can BuildInfo.language_version being Optional lead to packages compiled with incompatible Move language versions being loaded into the same VM, causing undefined behavior or type confusion attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Type: AddressDeclarations, Line: 14] [Address Collision] Can AddressDeclarations (BTreeMap<NamedAddress, Option<AccountAddress>>) allow multiple named addresses to map to the same AccountAddress, causing address collision attacks where malicious code gets access to legitimate package resources? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/source_package/parsed_manifest.rs] [Type: DevAddressDeclarations, Line: 15] [Dev Address Leak] Can DevAddressDeclarations be accidentally included in production builds, exposing test/development addresses that have weak security controls or known private keys, leading to unauthorized access?
